When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, it always needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after millions or even billions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the fate of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself occurs beyond the cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies that are intrinsically conditioned rather than socially conditioned.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of ownership of a car.

The possession of a large number of cars also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat bodily injuries.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 9th century BC, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and rebuilt it and christened it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in Morocco for shopping.

Goma is a tourist city located in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.

Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be done with research to understand the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the Bangladeshi and Indian backwaters.
The Sundarbans have been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located in India is called the Sundarbans National Park.
But forests are not composed only of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which about one third is covered by water/marshland.

The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 metres; it is 378 metres long and has two lanes of 3.50 metres wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was opened to traffic in March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guarani were the most important indigenous group inhabiting what is now the east of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes who inhabited the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly through fishing, hunting, or gathering.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP) which is equivalent to a British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank in the islands located at Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.

On the surrounding islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if British and American currency might be accepted. Talk to the owners beforehand to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has one foot caught in the saddle, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth sole and a narrow width.
